awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Preliminary Design and Manufacturing of Mooring Line Connections for  3D Concrete Printed Floating Wind Turbine Anchors
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Technology Transfer Research (STTR) Phase I project opens pathways to large-scale domestic manufacturing of low-cost energy infrastructure needed to facilitate the clean energy transition in the United States. The United States has a vast offshore wind energy resource that is nearly four times the nation's current electricity use. This enormous potential presents an opportunity to deliver clean and reliable electricity to the country’s largest population centers while creating hundreds of thousands of jobs to manufacture and service the wind plants. However, approximately 60% of the offshore wind energy resource is in deep waters that require floating wind turbines moored to seafloor anchors. With an installed cost of approximately $1 M each, lower-cost anchor solutions are needed to accelerate the deployment of wind energy. This Phase I project uses advanced additive manufacturing methods to cut the installed costs of wind turbine anchors. The additive manufacturing technology also has strong future market potential in diverse renewable energy technologies beyond anchors, including fixed-bottom offshore substructures, floating wind platforms, wave energy devices, on-shore wind turbine towers, small hydropower, and pumped hydro electric energy storage.  This project combines four cost-reducing innovations to create a low cost additively manufactured anchor that will cut installed anchor costs by up to 80% compared to conventional steel suction anchors – saving approximately $3M per floating wind turbine. 

The proposed project advances the following innovations: (1) the first-ever application of 3D concrete printing to floating wind turbines, (2) an innovative concrete reinforcement system, (3) integrated buoyancy chambers that aid transport and installation of the anchor, and (4) a new mooring line connection method, the development of which is the primary focus of the project.  The project goal is to pave the way for the first-ever seafloor embedment of the innovative concrete anchor by de-risking key aspects of a mooring line connection solution capable of resisting extreme mooring line forces of approximately 1,700 metric tons. The Phase I project scope includes comparison and down-selection of mooring line connection concepts, preliminary design of the selected design, fabrication of a section of the concrete anchor using additive manufacturing at a scale of up to 2.5 meters in diameter, and analysis of the cost effectiveness and production rates of the innovative anchor and additive manufacturing process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Introduction 

Floating offshore wind is rapidly emerging technology. Cost-effective and reliable anchoring of floating wind turbines is a major barrier to floating wind development. Existing steel anchors solutions have been adapted from the oil & gas sector and have not been optimized for mass manufacturing in quantities required of wind plants. RCAM has invented a 3D printed concrete suction anchor (3DPA) for offshore wind turbines that uses ubiquitous domestic concrete supply chains and is projected to reduce the installed cost of anchors up to 80% using automated concrete manufacturing (Fig. 1).

3DPA combines four primary innovations to cut installed anchors costs by up to 80% compared to steel suction anchors while utilizing the existing concrete supply chain to reach up to 100% domestic content. These innovations are (1) the first-ever application of 3DCP to floating wind turbines, (2) ?spiral post-tensioning? reinforcement, (3) a wet-towed transport and installation method, and (4) innovative mooring line connection designs ? the primary project focus. For this STTR project, RCAM Technologies collaborated with Purdue University (the STTR Research Institute), WSP USA (structural engineering firm), and InterMoor (global mooring and anchor solutions provider) to successfully achieve all project objectives.

Market Opportunity

The U.S. has a vast offshore wind energy resource of more than 4,200 gigawatts (GW), nearly four times the nation's current electricity use. This enormous potential presents an opportunity to deliver clean and reliable electricity to the country?s largest population centers while creating hundreds of thousands of jobs to manufacture and service the wind plants. Offshore wind has the potential to benefit all five coastal and Great Lakes regions of the U.S. as illustrated by the U.S. Department of Energy?s vision for 86 GW of offshore wind energy by 2050 (Fig. 2) which will require the installation of over 5000 new offshore wind turbines.

Over 60% of the US offshore wind energy resource is in deep waters that require floating wind turbines moored to the seafloor. However, floating wind costs are still several times higher than installing turbines on land and more expensive than fixed-bottom offshore wind plants. Next to the turbine and substructure, anchors and mooring are the most expensive components to manufacture and deploy. In addition to cost, anchor manufacturing also faces challenges in supply chain, availability and cost of installation vessels, and supporting local economic development. Innovations in offshore wind anchors are needed to reduce the cost of floating wind and solve critical challenges hindering its adoption.

RCAM is the only company in the word known to be developing concrete suction anchors for floating wind and the only company to apply 3DCP to marine structural applications including anchors. Conventional concrete methods such as slip forming, casting, or precasting have the potential to be used in conjunction with or instead of 3DCP to fabricate the 3DPA. However, RCAM?s automated additive manufacturing process facilitates increased production rates and reduces costs because it eliminates labor intensive operations making 3DCP RCAM's preferred manufacturing method for suction anchors.

Phase I Conclusions and Future Work

The purpose of Phase I was to prove the manufacturability and technoeconomic feasibility of the 3D printed concrete suction anchor for floating offshore wind plants, perform the conceptual design of the anchor?s mooring line connection, and plan follow-on laboratory structural testing of the mooring line connection. The project team accomplished the following:

  • Two preferred mooring line connections were down selected as preferred designs. Each concept was proven to be technically feasible to resist the extreme loads required for mooring 15 MW floating wind turbines.
  • The project team developed material formulations, toolpath generation processes, and manufacturing methodologies necessary to fabricate subscale 3DPA prototypes (Fig. 3).
  • Material durability testing demonstrated that the performance of 3DCP materials in marine installations can meet or exceed that of comparable cast concrete materials.
  •  The project team developed a feasible plan to structurally test the 3DPA mooring line connection (Fig. 4).
  • Technoeconomic analysis revealed that 3DPA reduces installed anchor CapEx by up to 80%.

Future work aims to demonstrate the feasibility of the hybrid steel/concrete anchor using sprayed concrete manufacturing and large scale proof testing of a pad eye concept.  

If awarded Phase II, RCAM will advance 3DPA via the following objectives:

1.     Development of automated sprayed 3DCP equipment, materials, and processes.

2.     Design refinement and fabrication of a 3DPA anchor prototype at up to 1:2 scale.

3.     Execute laboratory structural testing of a 3DPA mooring line connection at up to a 1:2 scale.

The execution of these objectives will further de-risk the 3DPA needed to attract public and private funding needed to commercialize the anchor. Commercializing 3DPA will substantially reduce the CapEx of US floating offshore wind plants, overcome sector-wide barriers in logistics and supply chain that are hindering the growth of offshore renewable energy, and increase local jobs and domestic economic benefits using localized 3DCP manufacturing.

 


Last Modified: 04/09/2023
Modified by: Jason Cotrell

Images (1 of )
  • Fig. 1: An artistic rendering of the 3D-printed suction anchor (3DPA) installed for different types of floating platform and mooring configurations.
    RCAM Technologies
    Copyrighted
    Jason Cotrell
    3D Printed Suction Anchor
  • Fig. 2. The distribution of a potential 86 GW offshore wind energy generation by 2050 from the DOE Wind Vision. The percentages indicate the shares contributed by each offshore wind region.
    DOE
    Copyrighted
    Jason Cotrell
    Potential US Offshore Wind Generation Potential
  • Fig 3. (left) Photographs of the 3D printed concrete prototype with spiral post-tensioning channels. (right) Photograph of the 1:8 scale 3DPA models showing the bolted and studded plate pad eye concepts. (bottom) Toolpath and 3D model of 3DPA prototype section.
    RCAM Technologies
    Copyrighted
    Jason Cotrell
    Digital Models and Proof of Concept Anchor Prototype
  • Fig.4: Schematic of the 1:2.5 scale mooring connection laboratory structural testing configuration.
    RCAM Technologies
    Copyrighted
    Jason Cotrell
    Phase 2 Structural Testing Configuration of a Suction Anchor
